qas.question: What's another term used for "conifer" wood?
What type of plants produce material that is referred to as "wood" even though it is technically not?
What monocot plant produces "wood" by the same name that's often used for flooring and veneer?
While we call bamboo "wood," what botanical family does it belong to?
Along with bamboo, what's the other monocot that's a major source of so-called "wood"?

context: Structural material that resembles ordinary, "<a0_0>dicot<a0_0/>" or conifer wood in its gross handling characteristics is produced by a number of <a1_0>monocot<a1_0/> plants, and these also are colloquially called wood. Of these, <a2_0>bamboo<a2_0/>, botanically a member of the <a3_0>grass<a3_0/> family, has considerable economic importance, larger culms being widely used as a building and construction material in their own right and, these days, in the manufacture of engineered flooring, panels and veneer. Another major plant group that produce material that often is called wood are the <a4_0>palms<a4_0/>. Of much less importance are plants such as Pandanus, Dracaena and Cordyline. With all this material, the structure and composition of the structural material is quite different from ordinary wood.
